newsitem.title: USA: Calif. electric utilities file to issue securities.
newsitem.headline: Calif. electric utilities file to issue securities.

text.p: California's three major investor-owned utilities have asked the state's Public Utilities Commission to approve their plan to issue up to $7.3 billion of "rate reduction bonds," documents showed Wednesday.

The securities are a key element of the state's plan to deregulate its electricity industry while allowing traditional monopoly utilities to recover investments made under the existing regulatory framework.

The bonds will lower the carrying costs on a portion of the utilities' "stranded costs" by spreading out the recovery over the 10-year life of the bonds. Stranded costs are investments such as nuclear power plants which are unlikely to be profitable under market competition.
The utilities plan to transfer the assets which will back the securities to special entities so that the bonds will be "bankruptcy remote."
Issuance of the securities through the state infrastructure bank is expected to begin in the fourth quarter.
The bonds are structured to enable the utilities to meet requirements for a 10 percent rate cut for small business and residential customers in the state between January 1, 1998 and March 31, 2002.

PG&E Corp's Pacific Gas and Electric Co applied to issue up to $3.5 billion in bonds, while Edison International's Southern California Edison Co is seeking approval to issue up to $3.0 billion and Enova Corp's San Diego Gas & Electric Co will issue up to $800 million in the new securities.
Actual issuance amounts are expected to be slightly below the requested amounts.
Each of the utilities said they intend to use net proceeds from the bond financing to reduce their capitalization, with the cuts roughly equal to current debt and equity ratios.
California state Treasurer Matt Fong on Wednesday announced the appointment of Lehman Brothers as the co-senior manager for the sale of $6 billion in rate reduction bonds this year.
Morgan Stanley will join Lehman in handling the PG&E and San Diego Gas & Electric securities, while Salomon Brothers will help manage Edison's portion.
Revenues to repay the bonds will come from separate, nonbypassable charges to be levied on the utilities' existing customers.
The actual amount of the charges -- which will show up as a special item on electricity bills -- will be determined by the Public Utilities Commission later this year.
